Description: Body sherd of top of Attic black-figured pottery covered cup with edge of orifice; interior: reserved; exterior: three black bands to centre; outside, below, black-figure decoration consisting of hunter chasing hare to right (part of naked bearded man with added red hair and red cloak on left arm remaining; left leg and arm lost; he probably held club in left hand; back and ears of hare); at right, vertical at edge of panel, setting off opening in cover, which is thought of as the hare's earth as well as the mouth of the cup; black outline of the opening preserved with most of a frontal eye above it.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd belongs to the same vase as Oxford AN1896-1908-G137.30b (which gives more of the hare hunting scene and part of a mounted hunting scene) and AN1896-1908-G137.43 (which shows part of the mounted hunting scene and part of the scene from the upper register). The covered cup is a rare shape. For parallels, see CVA Oxford II, 97.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 429, no. B686)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0718) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 97, pl. III, no. 23)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
